verses.text: When it was time for Elizabeth to have her baby, she gave birth to a son.
Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown her great mercy, and they shared her joy.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1
rsbNotes.text: 1:31 Jesus. The name means “Yahweh is salvation.”

verses.text: On the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to name him after his father Zechariah,
but his mother spoke up and said, "No! He is to be called John."
They said to her, "There is no one among your relatives who has that name."
Then they made signs to his father, to find out what he would like to name the child.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:59
rsbNotes.text: 1:59 the eighth day. Jewish circumcision was on the eighth day (Gen. 17:12), but this is the earliest evidence for the custom of naming on that day.

verses.text: He asked for a writing tablet, and to everyone's astonishment he wrote, "His name is John."
Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue was loosed, and he began to speak, praising God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:63
rsbNotes.text: 1:63 writing tablet. A writing tablet was a board covered with wax that could be written on with a pointed instrument.

verses.text: The neighbors were all filled with awe, and throughout the hill country of Judea people were talking about all these things.
Everyone who heard this wondered about it, asking, "What then is this child going to be?" For the Lord's hand was with him.
His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied:

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:65
rsbNotes.text: 1:65 fear. The emotion of awe and reverence appropriate to the presence of God.

verses.text: "Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel, because he has come and has redeemed his people.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:68
rsbNotes.text:
1:68 Blessed. A common way of beginning a thanksgiving (Ps. 72:18; 124:6).

redeemed. God’s people are not rescued without cost.

verses.text: He has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of his servant David
(as he said through his holy prophets of long ago),
salvation from our enemies and from the hand of all who hate us--

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:69
rsbNotes.text:
1:69 horn. The horn was a symbol of strength.

his servant David. This phrase shows that Zechariah is talking about Jesus, not John.

verses.text: to show mercy to our fathers and to remember his holy covenant,
the oath he swore to our father Abraham:
to rescue us from the hand of our enemies, and to enable us to serve him without fear
in holiness and righteousness before him all our days.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:72
rsbNotes.text: 1:72 his holy covenant. There are several covenants in the Old Testament, but that with Abraham was always seen as specially significant (Gen. 17).

verses.text: And you, my child, will be called a prophet of the Most High; for you will go on before the Lord to prepare the way for him,
to give his people the knowledge of salvation through the forgiveness of their sins,

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:76
rsbNotes.text: 1:76 you, child. Zechariah turns his attention to John and says he will be the forerunner of the Lord.

verses.text: because of the tender mercy of our God, by which the rising sun will come to us from heaven
to shine on those living in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the path of peace."

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:78
rsbNotes.text: 1:78 the sunrise. This refers to the Messiah (Mal. 4:2). The Greek means simply “rising,” and some think of a shoot from Jesse (Is. 11:1). But the word is commonly used of the “rising” of the sun, and so a reference to the dawn is more likely.

verses.text: And the child grew and became strong in spirit; and he lived in the desert until he appeared publicly to Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:80
rsbNotes.text: 1:80 in the wilderness. John grew up in the wilderness and may have had contact with religious communities like that at Qumran, an ascetic community whose writings, the Dead Sea Scrolls, were discovered in 1946.
